docs.lead_paragraph: Bonnie Bernstein has a 23-year-old son. She is nearly 50. And she wants to have a baby. She wrote about this yesterday on babble.com, in an essay titled "I'm Almost 50 and I Want to Get Pregnant, Am I The Only One?" and I read it with my mouth open. Unlike Bernstein, I spend a lot of time quite happy that I am not pregnant. It was lovely (well, parts of it). Twice. And now I'm done.
docs.abstract: Is Bonnie Bernstein the only woman who feels this way?
docs.snippet: Is Bonnie Bernstein the only woman who feels this way?

docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Fox Business Network) STOSSEL Forget, for a moment, received notions of civic responsibility. Should all Americans vote, regardless of their knowledge of the candidates and the issues at stake? John Stossel, above, presents the question to a panel that includes John Fund, a columnist for The Wall Street Journal Web site and the author of ''Stealing Elections: How Voter Fraud Threatens Our Democracy''; the political satirist P. J. O'Rourke; Andy Bernstein, a founder of HeadCount, an organization that encourages young people to vote; Roger Clegg, president of the Center for Equal Opportunity; Gov. Mitch Daniels, Republican of Indiana; and Michael C. Moynihan, a senior editor of Reason magazine. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES Brennan (Emily Deschanel) rethinks her relationship with Booth (David Boreanaz) when he arrives for a surprise visit with his girlfriend, a war correspondent (Katheryn Winnick). Meanwhile the team tries to identify a couple whose bodies were discovered in a cave in a national park. In ''Fringe,'' at 9, Olivia (Anna Torv) helps Peter (Joshua Jackson) and Walter (John Noble) investigate a strange box that seems to be sending people into trances from which they cannot emerge. Elsewhere, Walter attends a reading of William Bell's will.
